text: 5 gorgeous private islands you can visit by cruise ship Princess, Holland America and Royal Caribbean are among the lines with private hideaways Post to Facebook 5 gorgeous private islands you can visit by cruise ship Princess, Holland America and Royal Caribbean are among the lines with private hideaways  //usat.ly/2m7ABrF   Join the Nation's Conversation   5 gorgeous private islands you can visit by cruise ship Jodi Ornstein, Editor, Porthole Cruise Magazine Published 8:23 a.m. ET Feb. 22, 2017 | Updated 4 minutes ago Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Located about a mile off the coast of southern Belize, Harvest Caye is the Caribbean's newest cruise destination. Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Unveiled in November, Harvest Caye features a seven-acre beach, sprawling pool area, eateries, bars and shops. It also serves as a hub for tours to Mayan ruins and other sites on the mainland of Belize. Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Cruise ships arriving at Harvest Caye tie up at a newly built, multi-million dollar dock. Its construction was a milestone for Belize, which never has had a dock capable of receiving large passenger vessels. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Passengers streaming off cruise ships pass through an monumental gate to a faux Caribbean village filled with shops and food stands. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A store selling duty free alcohol is among the outlets tucked into Caribbean-style buildings in the Harvest Caye village area. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings has brought in local vendors to operate food and drink outlets on Harvest Caye. The shopping village area features local some favorites including an umbrella drink-in-a-coconut venue called Rum Coco. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Rum Coco serves up rum drinks in coconuts for $10. Non-alcoholic versions are $5. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Hand-made ice cream is on offer at the Harvest Caye village's Dulce's Island Ice Cream. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A giant sculpture of an iguana stands guard in the central part of the Harvest Caye village. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye's seven-acre beach comprises roughly 10% of the 78-acre island and is one of its top attractions for cruise ship visitors. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY More than 2,300 lounge chairs line Harvest Caye's beach, with hundreds more available around the island's massive pool. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings purchased Harvest Caye in 2013 and spent more than three years developing it as a beach-lined destination for cruise ship passengers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The development of Harvest Caye included the planting of thousands of palms along the beach and elsewhere on the island to give it a Caribbean hideaway feel. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The beach at Harvest Caye was completely man made and features a light sand. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY In addition to palms, yellow umbrellas sprinkled amongst the lounge chairs along the beach provide shade from the Belizean sun. They are available on a first-come, first-serve basis at no charge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Lounge chairs covered with protective clam shells also are available along the beach. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Mobile beach chairs for passengers with disabilities are available. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye's sprawling, palm-fringed pool measures 15,000 square feet. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Harvest Caye pool features a swim-up bar that is part of the island's main food and drink spot, the LandShark Bar & Grill. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Eight manned lifeguard stations ring the Harvest Caye pool. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY More than 300 lounge chairs surround the Harvest Caye pool, which has a bather capacity of 2,000 people. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Palm-dotted islets are located in the middle of the Harvest Caye pool. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Flanking one end of the Harvest Caye pool are private cabanas that can be rented for $249 per day for use by up to four people. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Kid's Splash Park at Harvest Caye features a giant dump bucket and other watery features. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye's main food and drink outlet, the LandShark Bar & Grill, is a branch of the growing chain developed by Jimmy Buffett's Margaritaville. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye's LandShark Bar & Grill is a two-floor structure with enclosed, air conditioned seating on the first floor and an open-air food and bar area upstairs. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Open-air seating on the second floor of Harvest Caye's LandShark Bar & Grill overlooks the island's beach and pool areas. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The LandShark Bar & Grill serves up such fare as burgers, chicken wings and Belizean shrimp ceviche for $9.75 to $14.99 a plate. Drinks start at $4 for a glass of wine, with margaritas starting at $8.50. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Locally made Belikin Lager is available at Harvest Caye's LandShark Bar & Grill for $5. All food and drink on the island is a la carte. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY At the far end of the Harvest Caye beach is a private area reserved for passengers who book one of the island's 11 beach front villas. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Each of the 11 private villas along the Harvest Caye beach are standalone structures with their own lounge chairs and umbrellas. They can be rented for $499 per day for use by up to six people. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Each private beach cabana at Harvest Caye features a private restroom and indoor and outdoor showers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Beach cabanas also come with butler and concierge service. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Each private beach cabanas has a deck area with four plush fabric-covered lounge chairs. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The interior of private beach cabanas are equipped for Bluetooth audio and have digital safes and mini refrigerators. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A seating area in a private beach villa. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY At the front of each private beach villa are two Adirondack-style chairs. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Each private beach villa also comes with a hammock strung between palms. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Laughing Bird Bar & Grill is a quiet venue found near the end of the beach by the private beach villas. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Modern and clean bathroom huts are located along the beach at Harvest Caye. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A building near the beach at Harvest Caye houses a beach rentals desk and a first aid station. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Lockers for storing valuables are located next to the Beach Rentals building near the Harvest Caye beach. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Receptacles for recyclables as well as regular garbage can be found across the island. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye also features a small salt-water lagoon where cruise passengers can rent two-person kayaks for $25 an hour. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Paddle boards and small electric float boats also are available for use on the small Harvest Caye lagoon for $20 and $45 per hour, respectively. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The icon of Harvest Caye is the Flighthouse, a 136-foot-tall tower shaped like a lighthouse that is the jumping off point for two zip lines that soar above the island. Zip line packages start at $65 per person. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY One of the first things passengers encounter after arriving at Harvest Caye is the Information and Guest Services station. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY In a nod to Belize's colonial past, a vintage British mail box is located near the Information and Guest Services building. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Bathrooms can be found just across from the Information and Guest Services building. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Small cannons at the entrance to Harvest Caye add to its Caribbean island charm. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Signs point the way from the pier to Harvest Caye's beach area and other attractions. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A thatched-roof hut in the village area serves up frozen daiquiris and other umbrella drinks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Stores in the village area mostly sell local products from Belize including jewelry. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Located at Harvest Caye's village area, Moho Chocolates sells organic chocolate products made from cocoa beans harvested at small Belize farms. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye also is home to a small, outdoor nature area that is open to cruisers at no charge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye's nature center includes a walk-through butterfly house filled with iridescent blue morpho butterflies. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Blue morpho butterflies are hatched on site at the Harvest Caye butterfly house. . Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Also in the Harvest Caye butterfly house are Isabella butterflies. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The butterfly house at the Harvest Caye nature center is filled with native plants. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Harvest Caye nature center also has an aviary for Toucans, the national bird of Belize. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A toucan sits on a perch at Harvest Caye's nature center. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Another icon of Belize, the Scarlet Macaw, also will be on display at Harvest Caye's nature center in the near future. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The boa constrictor on display at Harvest Caye's nature center once roamed the island. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye has a marina that serves as a hub for tours to the mainland of Belize. Gene Sloan, USA TODAYhc The Lady Marcia, named after the wife of Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings CEO Frank Del Rio, is one of several vessels that transport passengers between Harvest Caye's marina and the Belize mainland. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Boats taking tourgoers to the mainland from Harvest Caye arrive at the Malacate transportation hub, also developed by Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings. From there, buses depart for Mayan ruins and other attractions. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The marina entrance to Harvest Caye features a covered waiting area where passengers await boats to the mainland. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The open-air waiting area at Harvest Caye's marina was hand-crafted from local hardwoods. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Benches hewn from local hardwoods fill the waiting area at Harvest Caye's marina. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A local musical group greets cruise passengers at Harvest Caye. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A shade-covered seating area in the Harvest Caye village. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A hidden beach surrounded by mangroves at Harvest Caye. More than 15,000 mangroves were planted across the island during its development. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye employees use bicycles to run errands around the island. Electric carts also are available to transport passengers between zip line stations. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY One of the many stores around the Harvest Caye village area. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A warning sign along the beach at Harvest Caye. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Harvest Caye as seen from the air. Norwegian Cruise Line Like this topic?
